metadata.title: Microstructure and properties of sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Alloys and Compounds
journal homepage: http: / /www.elsevier .com/locate/ ja lcom
Microstructure and properties of sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings
Yuxin Wang a, *, Di Cao a, Weidong Gao a, Yanxin Qiao a, Yunxue Jin a, Guang Cheng b, **, Wei Gao c, Zheng Zhi d
a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Zhenjiang, 212003, Jiangsu, China b College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, 100029, China c Department of Chemical & Materials Engineering, The University of Auckland, PB 92019, Auckland, 1142, New Zealand d Department of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, Stony Brook University, NY, 11794, United States
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 18 December 2018 Received in revised form 27 March 2019 Accepted 3 April 2019 Available online 8 April 2019
Keywords: Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coating Sol-enhanced plating Mechanical properties Corrosion resistance
* Corresponding author.. ** Corresponding author..
E-mail addresses: ywan943@163.com (Y. Wang), g (G. Cheng).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2019.04.047 0925-8388/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Co-P coatings have been widely used as the replacement of hexavalent chromium coatings. In order to improve the properties of Co-P coatings, Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were prepared using a novel sol-enhanced method. The microstructure, mechanical properties and corrosion resistance of solenhanced Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were systematically investigated. The results show that sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coating with a good dispersion of TiO2 nanoparticles can be obtained by adding an appropriate amount of TiO2 sol to the bath. The microhardness of Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating was increased by ~18% compared to that of Co-P coating. Its wear resistance and corrosion resistance were also significantly improved. The effects of TiO2 sol concentration on the microstructure, mechanical properties and corrosion resistance of Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were discussed in detail.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hard chromium (Cr) coatings have beenwidely used in our daily life and modern industry because of their high hardness, excellent wear resistance and good corrosion resistance [1e4]. Currently, the most solutions used for Cr plating are based on hexavalent chrome (Cr6þ) plating bath, which is known as genotoxic carcinogens and are gradually prohibited in plating industry [5]. With the increasing demands of environmental protection, it is necessary to develop alternative coating systems other than Cr6þ plating [1e3].
Numerous studies have been conducted to prepare nickel (Ni) and cobalt (Co) based hard coatings to replace hard Cr coatings [6e13]. Among these coatings, Co-P coatings have attracted much interest. Traditionally, the Co-P coatings are prepared for their special magnetic and electrical properties [14,15], and less considered as hard coatings. The magnetic properties of Co-P coatings could be easily adjusted by the P content: coatings and alloys with less than 8 at. % P exhibit hard magnetic property; while those with
uangcheng@mail.buct.edu.cn
over 16 at. % P show soft magnetic property [14e16]. Meanwhile, amorphous phases were observed in the Co-P coatings when the atomic percentage of P was over 11 at. % P [4,11,17e19].
In recent years, hard Co-P coatings have been studied as the suitable materials for replacement of hard Cr coatings [17,20,21]. As the mechanical property of Co-P coatings prepared by direct current (DC) plating is comparatively lower than that of hard Cr, pulse current (PC) plating of Co-P composite coatings has been conducted, resulting in better mechanical properties than those deposited under DC plating [22,23]. However, the main drawback which hinders the large-scale production of Co-P PC plating is the relatively high cost compared to the other methods. To comprise the coating performances and product cost, various Co-P composite coatings were investigated. Second phase particles such as TiO2, SiC and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were added into the bath to achieve better mechanical properties through dispersion strengthening effect [10,20,24,25].
The mechanical properties of the composite coatings have been improved to a certain extent with the addition of the second phase. However, further improvements are constrained due to the high surface energy of nano-sized reinforcements which will agglomerate to large clusters. Furthermore, the surface appearance including the color, brightness and surface roughness will be
affectedwith an excessive amount of the second phase. To avoid the particles agglomeration, we have developed a novel method, namely, “sol-enhanced platingmethod”. This method combines the sol-gel process with electrochemical deposition to fabricate nanocomposite coatings. Fine nanoparticles are in-situ generated and directly deposited into the coating matrix. The mechanical properties of coatings can be significantly improved by the dispersion strengthening of highly dispersed nanoparticles [6,7,26,27]. The sol-enhanced plating method has been successfully applied in various coating systems, including Ni [28], Ni-B [29], Ni-P [9,30], NiCo [31], Au-Ni [32,33], and Zn-Ni [34,35], and different nanocrystalline-based coatings were prepared.
In the current research, the sol-enhanced plating method was attempted to fabricate Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings considering their promising applications. The microstructure of these new coatings has been foundmore complex containing nanosized grains, amorphous phase, and TiO2 nanoparticles. The strengthening effects from the small grains size [36], a combination of nanocrystalline and amorphous structures [37,38], and the dispersion of secondary phase particles [6,39] result in a significant property improvement. The microstructure, mechanical properties and corrosion resistance of sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nanocomposite coatings were comprehensively investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Sample preparation
sections.text:
The sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were electroplated onto mirror grade brass substrates (20 30 0.2mm3). Co-P coating without any reinforcement was prepared as the reference. Before electroplating, the brass substrates were ultrasonically cleaned in acetone at room temperature for 2min. Then these specimens were degreased in alkaline solution (50 g/L NaOH, 10 g/L NaH2PO4) at 65 C for 5min. The degreased specimens were activated in an acid solution (20 g/L C6H8O7, 60 g/L C6H17N3O7) under a current density of 50mA/cm2 at room temperature for 60 s. After thoroughly rinsing in the distilled water, the electroplating experiments were conducted on the specimens.
TiO2 sol was prepared as reported in the previous research [6,7,27]: 8.68mL of tetrabutylorthotitanate [Ti(OBu)4] was dissolved into the mixture solution of 35mL ethanol and 2.82mL diethanolamine. After magnetic stirring for 2 h, it was hydrolyzed by adding a mixture of 0.45mL deionized water and 4.5mL ethanol dropwise under magnetic stirring.
The electrodeposition system consists of a 99.9wt% pure cobalt plate as the anode and the pretreated brass substrate as the cathode. A cobalt sulfate containing electrolyte was used to electrodeposit both Co-P coating and sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coatings. Different amounts of TiO2 sol (0e50mL/L) were added into the bath slowly in order to achieve a good suspension in the electrolyte. The bath composition and plating parameters are presented in Table 1. All the electroplating tests were performed using a DC power supply (IT6721, ITECH, China). The coatings were denoted as Co-P-x mL/L TiO2 to describe the sample prepared using different TiO2 sol concentration.

sections.heading: 2.2. Sample characterization
sections.text:
The crystal structure of the coatings was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu Ka radiation (V¼ 30 kV, I¼ 15mA, l¼ 0.15406 nm). Diffraction patterns were recorded in the 2q range from 20 to 90 at a scanning step of 0.02 using Bruker D2 Phaser diffractometer. The surface morphology of Co-P-TiO2 nano-
composite coatings was observed using an optical microscope (Axioskop2-MAT, Zeiss, Germany). The cross-sectional microstructure and chemical compositions of coatings were analyzed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Gemini SEM 300, Zeiss, Germany) equipped with EDS. The grain size, nanoparticle size and the distribution of nanoparticles in the coating matrix was studied utilizing a high-resolution transmission electronmicroscope (TEM, JEM-2001F, JEOL, Japan). To prepare the TEM samples, the Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating was peeled off from the substrate and thinned by using a precision ion polishing system (PIPS Model 691, Gatan, USA).
The microhardness of Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings was measured using a Vickers indenter with a constant load of 50 g and a holding time of 15 s. The results for the hardness were the average of 5 measurements. The wear property of coatings was tested using a wear tester (UMT-2, CETR, USA) at 25 C under dry, nonlubricated conditions. The samples were tested linearly and a steel ball with a diameter of 9.58mm was used as the counter surface. All wear tests were carried out under a load of 5 N and a sliding speed of 30mm/s. The friction amplitude and testing time were set to be 6mm and 10min, respectively. The wear track images of the coatings were observed using the optical microscope after each test. The wear track volume was measured using the laser scanning confocal microscopy with an accuracy level of 10 18m3.
The corrosion resistance of the coatings was investigated in 3.5wt% NaCl electrolyte using an electrochemical workstation (CS2350, CorrTest, China). All measurements were conducted at 25 C using a typical three-electrode systemwith platinummesh as an auxiliary electrode, Ag/AgCl/KCl (sat.) electrode with Luggin probe as the reference electrode and coating sample as the working electrode. The exposed area of all samples was set to 1 cm2. The potentiodynamic polarization tests were conducted at a scanning speed of 1mV s 1. The corrosion current density and corrosion potential were obtained based on Tafel's extrapolation [40]. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were performed at open circuit potential (OCP) with an AC amplitude of 5mV in the frequency range of 10 kHz to 10MHz. To ensure the reproducibility of the obtained data, all corrosion tests were repeated at least for three times.

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD spectrum of coatings
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Co-P and sol-enhanced Co-PTiO2 nano-composite coatings. Both Co-P and sol-enhanced Co-PTiO2 nano-composite coatings present a wide peak around 45 and an inconspicuous small peak around 72.5 , which is consistent with
the previous observation from Vijayan et al. [4]. Such observation indicates that the current microstructure is dominant by the amorphousmatrix and includes certain nanocrystalline. The hybrid microstructure can be attributed to the appropriate current density, the addition of organic additives and high content of P. During the electrodeposition process, the formation of new crystal nucleus and the growth of crystals are simultaneous. Similar to our previous observations on other types of sol-enhanced coatings [7,9,28,29,33], no TiO2 were detected from the sol-enhanced Co-PTiO2 nano-composite coatings, probably due to the low quantity and high dispersion of the nanoparticles which will be further characterized by TEM.

sections.heading: 3.2. Surface morphology and cross-section of coatings
sections.text:
Fig. 2 presents the surface morphologies of Co-P and solenhanced Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings. All coatings exhibit a uniform morphology with a larger nodular structure surrounded by smaller nodules. As expectation, the addition of stress relieving agents benefits the processing which produced the coatings with no cracks on the surfaces. As the TiO2 sol content increases, no significant difference such as surface roughness can be seen on solenhanced Co-P-TiO2 coatings in Fig. 2(b and c). No obvious particles agglomeration or clusters were detected under the optical microscope.
Fig. 3 shows the cross-sectional morphology of Co-P and solenhanced Co-P-TiO2 coatings. The thickness of coatings is basically the same at the level of ~20 mm, indicating a similar deposition rate of ~0.44 mm/min. A clear and continuous boundary is detected between the coatings and brass substrates. All coatings do not have visible pores, abruption or cracks at the interfaces, indicating good adhesion between the coatings and substrates. Before tests, traditional scratch tests were performed on all the samples. The results show that all coatings present a good bonding performance. The cross-sectional morphology of coatings is consistent with the results of traditional tests. EDS results show that the P content of Co-P is ~9.23 at. % which ensures an amorphous phase dominated microstructures and is consisted with the XRD observation in Fig.1. No obvious TiO2 nano-particles agglomeration or TiO2 particles were seen in the cross-section of Co-P-TiO2 coatings, implying their extremely small size and high dispersion in the coatings. However, the EDS results indicating there is ~4.7 at. % Ti in sol-enhanced CoP-50mL/L TiO2 coating. It should be noted although the Ti element
was detected using EDS, the accurate amount of TiO2 should be determined by other methods such as inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS).

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical property of coatings
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the microhardness values of coatings with different TiO2 sol concentration. The microhardness of Co-P is ~626 HV50, a typical value of electroplating Co-P. The microhardness of the Co-PTiO2 nano-composite coatings is initially enhanced by increasing the amount of TiO2 sol concentration and reaches amaximumvalue of ~726 HV50 at 12.5ml/L. Further increasing the amount of TiO2 sol concentration to 50mL/L led to a decrease of microhardness to ~606 HV50, which is lower than that of the pure Co-P coating.
Previous studies show that the strengtheningmechanism of solenhanced nano-composite coatings is mainly attributed to two
aspects: dispersion strengthening and grain size refinement [27e29]. In order to further characterize the microstructure and clarify the strengthening mechanism, high-resolution TEM analysis of sol-enhanced Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating was conducted. Fig. 5 presents the diffraction patterns and bright image of the nanocomposite coating.
As the diffraction pattern shown in Fig. 5 (a), the sol-enhanced nano-composite coating exhibits a dominant amorphous phase structure which is consistent with the XRD results. Though the atom content of P is less than 10% in the currently deposited coating, we did not observe diffraction rings clearly compared to the previous study [4] with similar P content. This could be explained with the different processing parameters and the influence of the novel in-situ TiO2 nanoparticles. Then, nanoparticles with a size ranging from 20 to 35 nm distributed uniformly in the coating matrix as the spots highlighted in Fig. 5b. These nanoparticles contributed to the Ti observed in the EDS results of Fig. 3 and our previously research on TiO2 sol-enhanced Au-Ni coatings [32,33]. The size of TiO2 nanoparticles in Co-P-TiO2 coating is slightly larger than that we previously reported in the Au-Ni matrix (3e12 nm) [32]. The reason should be attributed to the different
operating conditions of the electrodeposition process. Based on our existing research [7,9,27,33], the size of TiO2 nanoparticles in the coating matrix can be greatly influenced by the pH value of electrolyte. Meanwhile, multiple clear thin lines, which apparently are the grain boundaries of nanocrystalline, were observed initiated from the TiO2 nanoparticles in the bright image. The size of the nanocrystalline would be 50e100 nm. The appearance of the nanocrystalline would indicate that the selected current density promoted the nucleation process, while the small addition of organic additives significantly increased the cathode polarization and restrained the crystal growth, resulting in the observed nanocrystalline structures near the TiO2 nanoparticles. It should be noted that the local nanocrystallization might be caused by the ion thinning processing during the sample preparation as well. However, high P content in the cobalt matrix broke the ordered structures and generated an amorphous phase dominated coating matrix.
The improvement of microhardness should bemainly attributed to the highly dispersed TiO2 nanoparticles in the Co-P coating matrix. The strengthening mechanism resulting from particles dispersion hardening is known as Orowan mechanism, which described as the highly dispersed nanoparticles can impede the mobility of the dislocations, thereby improving the hardness of materials [21e23]. During the sol-enhanced plating process of CoP-TiO2, the in situ formed TiO2 nanoparticles will be absorbed onto the deposited surface and incorporated into the growing Co-P
coating matrix. When the proper amount of TiO2 sol is added into the electrolyte, highly dispersed nanoparticles in the Co-P coating matrix play a role as a secondary phase and significantly enhance the hardness of coating [30,31]. However, too much sol addition will cause agglomeration of nanoparticles both in the electrolyte and Co-P matrix, resulting in large TiO2 particles and porosity, as shown in Fig. 6. These defects within the coatings weaken the mechanical performances of coatings.
The characteristic results show that the sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coatings present a complex “hybrid” microstructure. It would be difficult to quantify the contribution as the microstructure was mixed with amorphous and crystal phases [37,38]. Further study with nanoindentation will provide more detailed information for the phase properties and volume fractions [41e43].
Thewear track images andwear volume loss of Co-P coating and sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coatings are shown in Figs. 7 and 8. It can be seen that the Co-P coating has a relatively wide wear track and large volume loss of ~190 mm and ~1.35 10 14m3, respectively. Clear plowing lines and large wear debris can be observed on the worn surface. The main wear mechanical Co-P coating is the adhesive wear, which is quite common among electroplated metallic coatings. After adding 12.5mL/L TiO2 sol into the electrolyte, the wear track width and volume loss decreased to ~125 mm and ~0.25 10 14m3, respectively. However, the Co-P-50mL/L TiO2 coating exhibits the widest wear track width, ~207 mm, and the largest volume loss, ~1.90 10 14m3.
Fig. 9 presents the average friction coefficient of Co-P coating and sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nanocomposite coatings. The average friction coefficient of Co-P coating is ~0.42. Comparing with the 0.66 reported by the previous study [23], this relatively low value should be attributed to the high surface smoothness. The use of mirror grade substrate and stress relieving agents made the coating surface more uniform and free of cracks. Similar with the tendency of coating hardness, the average friction coefficient of Co-P12.5mL/L TiO2 coating was decreased to the minimum value of ~0.31, while that of Co-P-50mL/L coating was increased to ~0.44. The variation of friction coefficient can be interpreted by the incorporation of nanoparticles. Highly dispersed nanoparticles embedded into the coating matrix may play a role of solid lubricant during the wear process. However, too much addition of sol causes agglomeration of nanoparticles and leads to a high porosity in the coating matrix, thereby increasing the friction coefficient [21,23].
The wear behaviors of coatings are affected by the hardness, surface roughness, microstructure, friction coefficient andwear test setups. According to Archard's law, under the same wear test conditions, the wear rate is inversely proportional to the material hardness and proportional to the friction coefficient [18]. The tribological properties of Co-P coating and sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nanocomposite coatings basically follow this rule.

sections.heading: 3.4. Corrosion resistance of coatings
sections.text:
The potentiodynamic polarization curves of Co-P coating and sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coatings are presented in Fig. 10. The corresponding corrosion parameters, including corrosion potentials, corrosion current densities and corrosion rates of coatings were obtained from the extrapolation method and listed in Table 2.
Typically, the more positive corrosion potential and the smaller the corrosion current show a better corrosion resistance. The corrosion rate directly reflects the ability of the coating to resist corrosion to a certain extent [8]. The corrosion rate of pure Co-P
coating is ~0.038mm/year. The corrosion rate was decreased significantly with the increasing amount of TiO2 sol when the addition was below 12.5mL/L. Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating possesses the best corrosion properties as it has the lowest corrosion
rate of ~0.010mm/year. Further increasing the amount of sol led to an increase in corrosion rate. The corrosion rate of Co-P-50mL/L TiO2 coating was increased to ~0.113mm/year, which is higher than that of Co-P coating.
EIS tests were carried out to further investigate the corrosion behavior of coatings. Nyquist diagram and Bode plots were presented and compared in Fig. 11. All the tested samples exhibit semicircle with a single capacitive loop in the high-frequency region that indicates a charge controlled reaction [44]. The Nyquist plot exhibits depressed semicircle with a single capacitive loop in the high-frequency region, indicating a charge controlled reaction. As shown in Fig. 11a and b, Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating has the best corrosion resistance than the other coatings as it exhibits the largest radius of the capacitive loop and the highest value of jZjf/0 (~46.77 kU cm2). The Bode plots in Fig. 11c depicts that only one wave crest in the phase angle curves, indicating that there is only one time constant.
A fitting equivalent circuit model was applied as presented in Fig. 12. In this equivalent circuit model, Rs represents the solution resistance, Rct represents the charge transfer resistance and is inversely proportional to corrosion rate, and CPE is the constant phase element which can provide information about the polarity and the amount of charge at the surface/electrolyte interface [21,23,45,46]. The related electrical parameters based on this model are calculated and listed in Table 3. The simulated values of Rs for all coatings are in the level of ~10 Ucm2, which are clearly lower than that of Rct, indicating a stable testing environment. The Rct of Co-P12.5ml/L TiO2 coating is ~46.77 kU cm2, which is much higher than that of other coatings as well as the highest corrosion resistance among all specimens. On the contrast, the Rct of Co-P-50ml/L TiO2 coating is only ~4.914 kU cm2, even lower than that of Co-P coating (~16.23 kU cm2). The comparison reveals that too much TiO2 doping will significantly reduce the corrosion resistance of the coatings. The EIS results are in a good agreement with the results from potentiodynamic polarization tests.
The effects of TiO2 sol addition on the corrosion resistance of composite coatings can be evaluated from several aspects including composition, grain size, particle distribution, structural evolution, reduction of the effective metallic area exposed to the corrosive medium, and impediment of corrosion caused by inert particles [8]. In the present study, the highly dispersed nanoparticles in the grain boundary areas significantly reduce the micro holes and defects, resulting in a uniform and compact microstructure. In addition, these nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 5 (b), are pinned in the matrix and acted as the inert physical barriers during the corrosion process, substantially increasing the anticorrosion ability of the coatings. However, excessive addition of TiO2 sol would cause a heterogeneous distribution of nanoparticles and excessive interfaces in the coating matrix, and lead to a porous structure of coatings, thereby deteriorating the corrosion resistance. As reported by previous research [22,23], Co-P coatings prepared by pulse current (PC) and pulse reverse current (PRC) methods exhibit
higher corrosion resistance and wear resistance than that deposited by direct current (DC) method. Deeper exploration based on PC and PRCmethods will be conducted in the future in order to further enhance the property of sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coating.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: Sol-enhanced electroplating method was introduced to improve the property of Co-P coating. Sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 nanocomposite coatings were prepared and their microstructure, mechanical properties, and corrosion resistance were systematically investigated. The results show that the mechanical properties and corrosion resistance of coatings have been significantly improved by adding 12.5mL/L of TiO2 sol into the electrolyte. The microhardness of Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating was increased by ~18% compared to that of Co-P coating, and the corresponding wear resistance and corrosion resistance have also been greatly enhanced. Further research will be conducted on sol-enhanced composite coatings plated by Pulse Current and Pulse Reverse Current methods.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This research was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (51601073), Jiangsu Distinguished Professor Project (1064901601), Start research fund of Jiangsu University of Science and Technology (1624821607-5), and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (buctrc201827). The authors would like to express our gratitude to Mr. Haixin Zhu, Mr. Lin Zhang and technical staff in Jinshi Electroplating Ltd. We also express our gratitude to Glen Slater and Chris Goode and the technical staff in Cirrus Materials Science Ltd.

The effects of TiO2 sol addition on the corrosion resistance of composite coatings can be evaluated from several aspects including composition, grain size, particle distribution, structural evolution, reduction of the effective metallic area exposed to the corrosive medium, and impediment of corrosion caused by inert particles [8].

As reported by previous research [22,23], Co-P coatings prepared by pulse current (PC) and pulse reverse current (PRC) methods exhibit higher corrosion resistance and wear resistance than that deposited by direct current (DC) method.

metadata.abstractText: Co-P coatings have been widely used as the replacement of hexavalent chromium coatings. In order to improve the properties of Co-P coatings, Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were prepared using a novel sol-enhanced method. The microstructure, mechanical properties and corrosion resistance of solenhanced Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were systematically investigated. The results show that sol-enhanced Co-P-TiO2 coating with a good dispersion of TiO2 nanoparticles can be obtained by adding an appropriate amount of TiO2 sol to the bath. The microhardness of Co-P-12.5mL/L TiO2 coating was increased by ~18% compared to that of Co-P coating. Its wear resistance and corrosion resistance were also significantly improved. The effects of TiO2 sol concentration on the microstructure, mechanical properties and corrosion resistance of Co-P-TiO2 nano-composite coatings were discussed in detail. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
